title: Does Sprague Grundy help solve any impartial games that don't comprise independent sub games (combinatorial game theory)? - Quora

response.answer_text: A single Nim-heap is admittedly not a very interesting game. The Sprague-Grundy theorem is constructive; it tells us that a position’s Nim-value is the minimal excluded value of its successor’s Nim-values. Admittedly, this is not a significant advance over saying that a game is a P-position if all its followers are N-positions, and is a N-position if at least one of its followers is a P-position. So, if you don’t have a combinations of independent positions, the nimber provides no additional information about the winner. But, sometimes calculating Nim-values can help establish a periodic sequence of P- and N-positions. At a very basic level, S-G helps establish a test for when a subtraction game or octal game has become periodic, though this can be accomplished without it— see What is a proof that all subtraction games are ultimately periodic? We could also show that a game is *not* periodic by showing an aperiodic Grundy function (such as one with unboundedly large values.) There may also be cases where a game that is not explicitly decomposable at has some invariant or optimal line of play that can be understood as a sum of games— but I admit I can’t come up with an example at the moment.
